Research Paper Aerobic oxidation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural to 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid by modification of the crystalline structure of MnO2 for catalytic purposes Wenbo Liao Writing – original draft Methodology Formal analysis Conceptualization a 1 Shibo Yang Writing – review & editing Validation Formal analysis a 1 Yadong Liu Visualization Investigation Data curation a Qing Yin Methodology Formal analysis a Xing Tang Resources Project administration a Lu Lin Supervision Resources a Yong Sun Writing – review & editing Supervision Project administration Funding acquisition a b ⁎ a Xiamen Key Laboratory of Clean and High-valued Utilization for Biomass, College of Energy, Xiamen University, Xiamen 361102, China Xiamen Key Laboratory of Clean and High-valued Utilization for Biomass College of Energy Xiamen University Xiamen 361102 China aXiamen Key Laboratory of Clean and High-valued Utilization for Biomass, College of Energy, Xiamen University, Xiamen 361102, China b Fujian Engineering and Research Center of Clean and High-valued Technologies for Biomass, College of Energy, Xiamen University, Xiamen 361102, China Fujian Engineering and Research Center of Clean and High-valued Technologies for Biomass College of Energy Xiamen University Xiamen 361102 China bFujian Engineering and Research Center of Clean and High-valued Technologies for Biomass, College of Energy, Xiamen University, Xiamen 361102, China ⁎ Corresponding author. 1 The author contributes equally. Investigating the various polymorphs of MnO2 for the catalytic oxidation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) to 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) is motivated by the pressing demand to engineer sustainable and proficient catalytic pathways. These pathways are essential for transforming renewable biomass into valuable chemicals, thereby facilitating the shift towards a circular economy and diminishing our dependence on fossil fuel-derived resources. Herein, three MnO2 catalysts with different crystal structures were prepared for the efficient catalytic oxidation of HMF to FDCA. The results showed that α-MnO2 exhibited higher oxidizing activity per unit specific surface area and an appreciably large specific surface area, however, its overall catalytic activity was found to be less than that of β-MnO2. XRD, SEM, and other characterizations suggest that the presence of smaller nanorods or amorphous particles with reduced crystallinity on the surface of the α-MnO2 catalysts could be responsible for a decreased lattice oxygen content, thereby diminishing their catalytic activity. To validate this conjecture, this paper cites for the first time the application of a dilute nitric acid immersion treatment in the chemical industry to eliminate amorphous structures from catalysts. The α-MnO2-H+ catalyst, prepared using this innovative method demonstrated exceptional activity in facilitating the conversion of HMF to FDCA under more stringent reaction conditions than any monometallic catalysts previously reported. According to the kinetic analysis of the reaction, it was established that the oxidation of 5-formyl-2-furancarboxylic acid (FFCA) to FDCA constitutes the rate-limiting step within the entire oxidation process. On this basis, FT-IR studies showed that the oxidation initiates at the -CHO terminus of HMF, leading to the formation of intermediates 5-hydroxymethylfurfurylacetic acid and 5-formylfurfurylacetic acid within the Mn4+/Mn3+ redox cycle. In conclusion, the enhancement of catalytic activity by diluting nitric acid immersion treatment presents a promising avenue for further research and application in the field of green chemistry. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords 5-hydroxymethylfurfural 5-furandicarboxylic acid Catalytic oxidation MnO2 Lattice oxygen Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction With rapid economic growth and increasing energy consumption, which has led to a decline in fossil energy reserves (coal, oil, natural gas), the search for renewable resources is now a priority [1,2]. Among the chemicals that are abundant and renewable and are expected to be effective alternatives to fossil energy sources, 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) has a good potential value. Because it can be condensed with ethylene glycol to produce polyethylene 2,5-furandicarboxylate (PEF), it is an effective substitute for ethyl terephthalate (PET), which plays an important role in the petroleum industry [3–6]. Therefore, the developed efficient catalysts for the catalytic oxidation of HMF to FDCA are crucial for the sustainable development of biomass materials [7]. Many kinds of non-homogeneous catalysts (Au, Pt, Ru, etc.) have been reported for the synthesis of 5-hydroxymethyl furfural (HMF) to FDCA[2, 8]. Zheng et al. [9] obtained 97% FDCA yield in 6 h using a Ru@C catalyst with Mg(OH)2 as the base additive. However, due to drawbacks such as the high cost of precious metals and scarcity of resources, the synthesized low-cost non-precious metal catalysts have become more attractive [10,11]. Mn-based catalysts stand out among the metal choices for catalysts for the preparation of HMF due to their excellent oxidation performance during HMF oxidation. The oxidation of HMF follows the Mars-Van Krevelen mechanism, Mn contributes to the generation of lattice oxygen, which promotes the oxidation of HMF [12]. In recent years, many reports have pointed out that the synergy of Mn with other metals (Fe, Co, Cu, Bi, Ce, etc.) provided excellent selectivity for the oxidation of HMF [9,13]. Han et al. [14] developed a MnOx-CeO2 catalyst by co-precipitation method, which can efficiently oxidize HMF at a lower temperature (373 K). The addition of CeO2 effectively improved the catalytic activity and selectivity compared to a single MnOx catalyst, which plays an important role in the catalytic process with a large amount of Mn4+ and Ce3+ on the surface as active sites for HMF oxidation. Liu et al. [15] used a green ascorbic acid-assisted grinding method to increase the oxygen vacancy (Ov) concentration of the Mn-Co spinel catalyst obtaining an FDCA yield of 96% in 3 h under air atmosphere Their method indicated the feasibility and superior performance of Mn-based catalysts for catalyzing HMF to FDCA. However, bimetallic catalysts cannot be completely and uniformly dispersed during the preparation process, and some of them may be less active during large-scale production, so finding a way to improve the catalytic activity of monometallic catalysts has become a hot research topic at present. The currently reported methods to improve the catalytic activity of Mn metal are all modification methods. Yui et al. [16] modified and prepared a mesoporous β-MnO2 nanoparticle catalyst, which has a much narrower pore size distribution and ensures that O2 is the only oxidant in the reaction. Thus, the reaction is promoted efficiently. However, most of the currently reported modification methods for Mn-based catalysts work only on β-MnO2 (because β-MnO2 is the thermodynamically stable phase in the polycrystalline state of MnO2), and they do not work significantly on other crystalline types of MnO2, so finding a modification method that can generally improve the catalytic activity of Mn-based catalysts has become a hot topic of the current research. In this paper, we prepared three different crystalline types of MnO2 (α-MnO2, β-MnO2, and γ-MnO2) and characterized the structures and properties of different crystalline types of MnO2 to gain insights into their catalytic mechanisms. Afterward, a new α-MnO2-H+ catalyst was obtained by nitric acid immersion treatment, which could obtain a 98.5% FDCA yield within 6 h. To the best of our knowledge, its catalytic efficiency exceeds that of most single-metal catalysts and most double-doped non-precious-metal catalysts accessible to date. Therefore, the nitric acid modification method has great research prospects. 2 Experimental Section 2.1 Synthesis of α-MnO2 (α-MnO2-H+) with high specific surface area α-MnO2-H+ was synthesized according to the following procedure: 0.01 mol KMnO4 and 0.025 mol Mn (NO3)2·4H2O were mixed in a mortar of agate material and ball-milled for 20 min; after ball-milling, the mixed powder was added into a glass container and heated in a shaker apparatus at 60 °C for 4 h. After cooling to room temperature, the powder was repeatedly rinsed with cold water After cooling to room temperature, the powder was repeatedly rinsed with cold water and then dried in an oven at 60 °C overnight. The prepared α-MnO2 was shaken with dilute HNO3 in a sealed reactor at 60 °C for 8 h. The α-MnO2-H+ catalyst was obtained after treatment. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The synthetic MnO2 samples were identified by Cu Kα-ray radiation (λ=1.5405 Å, 40 kV-40 mA) as well as by X-ray diffraction (XRD) using the fourth generation of the latest combined multifunctional high-resolution diffractometer in the Ultima series manufactured by RIKEN, Japan. The minimum step was 0.0001°, and data were collected in the range of 2 θ from 0.5° to 159°. The analysis of XRD data was performed in MDI Jade6 software. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM, SUPRA55 SAPPHIRE) was used to observe the morphology of the samples. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms (Micromeritics ASAP 2020 HD88) and Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) methods were used at 80 K to calculate the specific surface area (SSA) and total porosity of the catalysts. Photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) data of X-rays were collected by PHI-5300/ESCA spectrometer and the measured spectra were fitted by XPS Peak 4.1 software. The in-situ Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were detected by a Frontier FT-IR spectrometer (Nicolet Is5), and the spectra were recorded in the range of 4000-1100 cm-1, and the obtained results were analyzed by the OMSNIC software. The metal leaching rate in the reaction solution was determined by ICP-OES (Thermo Scientific iCAP 7200). O2-programmed temperature rise desorption (O2-TPD) and H2-programmed temperature rise reduction (H2-TPR) were measured using a fully automated multi-purpose adsorption instrument (Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920), and corresponding thermograms are provided. For O2-TPD analysis, approximately 30 mg of the sample was preheated with a He gas stream at 473°C for 0.5 h and then cooled to 50°C. The samples were purged in a 3% O2/He (30 mL·min-1) gas stream for 0.5 h, followed by another purge with He (30 mL·min-1) for 0.5 h. When the reactor was heated to 800°C in the He streams and the ramp temperature reached 10°C·min-1, the O2 -TPD signal. Before H2-TPR analysis, O2-TPD was preheated using the same method for about 30 mg of catalyst. After this, the sample was swept at 10% H2/Ar (30 mL·min-1) until a stable baseline was obtained and then the purging was stopped. Subsequently, the H2-TPR signal was recorded when the temperature was increased from 50°C to 800°C and the ramp rate reached 10°C·min-1. 2.3 Procedure for catalytic oxidation All catalytic oxidation reactions in this study were carried out in a 50 ml Teflon high-pressure hydrothermal reactor with its pressure gauge or in a 30 ml Teflon high-pressure reactor with a special heating jacket (54 × 44 mm). The catalytic oxidation procedure for HMF was as follows: HMF (0.2 mmol), Catalyst (0.0256 g), NaHCO3 (0.4 mmol), H2O (2.5 ml), and O2 (2 MPa) were added to a high-pressure hydrothermal reactor and reacted at 120 °C for 8 h. After the reaction was complete, the catalyst was collected by centrifugal separation, and the catalyst was recovered and washed, then dried overnight at 100 °C 2.4 Product analysis The content of the individual substances in the reaction solution was determined by high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) with a Waters Alliance HPLC equipped with an HPX-87 H column (column oven temperature of 333 K) and a UV-VIS detector. The mobile phase of the HPLC was aqueous H2SO4 (278 μL of 98% H2SO4 in 1 L of ultrapure water) and the organic phase was aqueous methanol (1:4 ratio of methanol to ultrapure water). The quantitative analysis of the products was performed by external standard methods using authentic standards. The conversion of HMF, the yield of HMFCA/DFF/FDCA/FFCA, and the formation rate of FDCA were calculated by equations (1-3). (1.1) C H M F ( % ) = ( 1 − m o l e o f H M F in t h e p r o d u c t s i n i t i a l m o l e o f H M F ) × 100 % (1.2) Y X ( % ) = m o l e o f X in t h e p r o d u c t s i n i t i a l m o l e o f H M F × 100 % ( X = D F F , H M F C A , F F C A , F D C A ) (1.3) F D C A f o r m a t i o n r a t e ( m o l · g − 1 · h − 1 ) = m i c r o m o l e o f F D C A in t h e p r o d u c t s r e a c t i o n t i m e c a t a l y s t w e i g h t × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural characterization of α-MnO2, β-MnO2, and γ-MnO2 MnO2 is known for its diverse structural forms, each of which can influence the catalyst's performance. To evaluate the impact of these structures on the catalytic properties of MnO2 catalysts, various forms of α-, β-, and γ-MnO2 were synthesized and analyzed (refer to the Supporting Information for synthesis details) [17,18]. The synthesized MnO2 samples were initially examined using XRD (Fig. 1 a and S1). The XRD patterns matched those reported previously for α-MnO2 (JCPDS 00-044-0141), tetragonal β-MnO2 (JCPDS 00-024-0735), and orthogonal γ-MnO2 (JCPDS 00-014-0644), respectively [19]. Taking α-MnO2 as an example, the data were refined and analyzed in MDI Jade6 software, and the obtained lattice parameters (tetragonal, a = 4.40 Å, c = 2.87 Å) were in general agreement with the previous reports [20]. The lower crystallinity of β-MnO2 may be due to the relatively low synthesis temperature, leading to incomplete homogeneity. Notably, increasing the synthesis temperature for β-MnO2 was found to decrease its catalytic activity (Table S1), possibly due to agglomeration of nano-metal particles as observed in SEM images (Figure S2), which reduces metal dispersion and active site availability. The XRD pattern for β-MnO2 was smoother than those for α-MnO2 and γ-MnO2, with sharper and fewer miscellaneous peaks, suggesting a superior crystal structure. A well-ordered crystal structure is typically associated with increased exposure of active sites on the catalyst's metal, enhancing catalytic activity. The metal contents and the average oxidation states (AOS) of the MnO2 samples in different crystal forms were measured using ICP-AES (Table 1 ). The mass fractions of Mn in the three MnO2 catalysts varied from 57.15 to 63.51 wt%. The Mn content of α-MnO2 was lower than that of λ-MnO2, which may contain interlayer cations or water, both of which contribute to a stable structure. The AOS for all three MnO2 forms was between 3.7±1 and 3.9±1, which was in good agreement with the previously reported result [21]. The SEM images of synthesized MnO2 crystals in various forms are presented in Fig. 2 , with their morphological characteristics and average particle sizes documented in Table 1. The particles of α-, β- and γ-MnO2 exhibit a cluster-like structure made up of nanorods. Notably, the SEM images of β-MnO2 display a smoother, fine needle-like morphology, akin to the XRD findings, and show fewer impurities compared to α-MnO2 and γ-MnO2. Specifically, α-MnO2's surface features needle-like protrusions. It has been suggested that due to the non-uniformity of the calcination process, some nanorods may have lower crystallinity and be surrounded by amorphous impurities, which could account for these needle-like structures being remnants of incompletely calcined amorphous material. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) analysis, which is based on N2 adsorption isotherms, was used to determine the specific surface area and porosity of the MnO2 samples with different crystalline structures (Table 1& Fig. 1 (b, c)). All three MnO2 catalysts possess characteristic mesoporous structures, as evidenced by type IV isotherms and type H1 hysteresis loops. The findings align with SEM results and previous studies [22]. In particular, α-and β-MnO2 exhibit relatively high specific surface area and porosities, with α-MnO2 having a specific surface area of 80 ± 1 m2·g−1, which is approximately twice that of β-MnO2 at 44±1 m2·g−1. 3.2 Catalyst activity evaluation 3.2.1 Screening of HMF oxidation catalysts The oxidation of HMF was conducted using twice the molar amount of NaHCO3 (relative to HMF) and 2 MPa of O2 using various crystalline forms of MnO2 as catalysts (Table 2 ). The introduction of all three MnO2 catalysts led to a high conversion of HMF (89%-99%), but the yield of FDCA was disappointingly low, hovering between 40% and 70%. Notably, β-MnO2 demonstrated a comparatively higher FDCA yield, with a significant portion of the product remaining in the 5-formyl-2-furoic acid (FFCA) phase, as determined by Waters Alliance HPLC. To assess the stability of each catalyst post-HMF oxidation, the recovered catalysts were subjected to XRD analysis, with results depicted in Figures S3-S5. It was observed that the XRD patterns of the newly synthesized and recovered α- and β-MnO2 crystals exhibited minimal changes in peak positions, although there was a slight decrease in peak intensities. This could be attributed to particle agglomeration in the recovered α- and β-MnO2 catalysts, leading to the formation of larger particles, a hypothesis supported by the SEM images of the recovered catalysts. These findings indicate that both α- and β-MnO2 catalysts maintain relatively high stability following the reaction. In contrast, some of the XRD peaks of the recovered γ-MnO2 showed partial angular shifts compared to the fresh γ-MnO2, particularly the (110), (310), (420), and (601) peaks. This shift has been previously suggested as a possible outcome of the partial single-cell expansion of the γ-MnO2 structure following catalytic oxidation. Due to its lack of recyclability, γ-MnO2 is not considered suitable for industrial application, and further modification is not pursued. The catalytic oxidation of HMF to FDCA by MnO2 crystals as a catalyst involves a series of intricate reaction stages, making it challenging to gauge the inherent reactivity of the MnO2 catalyst in this process. Nevertheless, reaction kinetics can be employed to identify the rate-limiting steps in the MnO2-catalyzed oxidation of HMF to FDCA, with Fig. 3 illustrating the potential reaction pathways for this transformation. Taking α-MnO2 as a case study, the intermediates in the oxidation of HMF to FDCA were examined at various time intervals (2-8 hours). By treating all reaction steps as first-order reactions, kinetic modeling was conducted, yielding rate constants of k1=4.3 × 10-4 s-1, k2=2.7 × 10-3 s-1, k3=1.4 × 10-3 s-1, k4=3.5 × 10-2 s-1, and k5=3.1 × 10-5 s-1. Notably, k2 is approximately an order of magnitude greater than k1, suggesting that the primary pathway for activating MnO2 involves the initial oxidation of HMF to 5-hydroxymethylfurfural calcium (HMFCA), followed by the conversion to 5-formyl-2-furoic acid (FFCA) and ultimately to FDCA. The significantly smaller value of k5, in comparison to the other constants, indicates that the oxidation of FFCA to FDCA is likely the rate-determining step, as inferred from the reaction rate's dependence on oxygen pressure. The presence of two intermediates, HMCA, and FFCA, was demonstrated by high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) detection of the intermediates of the reaction (Figuer S12). To assess the effectiveness of various crystalline forms of MnO2 in catalyzing the oxidation of FFCA to FDCA, the reaction was monitored for 1.5 hours using FFCA samples with a purity of 99% (Table 3 ). According to the measured data, the initial rates of FFCA oxidation by the MnO2 catalysts of different crystalline structures were as follows: α-MnO2 (14.1 μmol·h-1·m-2) > β-MnO2 (9.8 μmol·h-1·m-2) > γ-MnO2 (8.3 μmol·h-1·m-2). Given that the specific surface areas of these two catalysts are comparable, it can be concluded that α-MnO2 exhibits a relatively superior capacity to catalyze the oxidation of FFCA into FDCA. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was conducted on the three MnO2 catalysts, with the XPS spectra of Mn 2p and O 1s being depicted in Fig. 4 . The deconvolution results were also detailed in Table S2. It was observed by the Mn 2p XPS spectra that all three different crystalline forms of Mn were present at Mn (II), Mn (III), and Mn (IV) valences. This observation is intriguing and suggests that the catalytic activity is distributed across the surfaces of all three MnO2 catalysts. The AOS of α-, β-, and γ-MnO2 are 3.9, 4.0, and 3.8, respectively. Higher AOS demonstrates superior oxidation performance in the reaction. The average oxidation state (AOS) derived from the Mn 2p spectra can be correlated with the empirical equation 1.4 [23]: (1.4) A O S = 9.27 − 1.18 Δ E s ( Δ E s s t a n d s f o r t h e b i n d i n g e n e r g y d i f f e r e n c e o f M n 2 p ) The valence state of manganese (Mn) in the catalysts is pivotal to their selectivity, and thus, the Mn valence state was further investigated using XPS (Fig. 4b). Notably, the three catalysts exhibit significant variations in the Mn 2p region, and the 2p electrons curves were deconvoluted into a bimodal distribution corresponding to 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 peak, with a peak area ratio of 2:1. The binding energies associated with Mn2+, Mn 3+, and Mn4+ species are 642.3 eV, 646.1 eV, and 653.8eV, respectively [24]. Previous studies [3] indicate that the catalytic process involving Mn-based catalysts involves interconversion among Mn2+, Mn3+, and Mn4+ states, in which the conversion between low-valent Mn and high-valent Mn (Mn2+ and Mn4+) being particularly influential in determining catalytic strength. It is observed that the ratio of low-valent to high-valent Mn in β-MnO2 is 71.2%, which is substantially higher than that of the other two catalysts, α-MnO2 (58.9%) and γ-MnO2 (56.1%)), This disparity may account for the enhanced catalytic activity observed in β-MnO2. This indicates that the transformation between Mn2+ and Mn4+ is more intense in β-MnO2, which can promote lattice generation. This corresponds to the reason for the superior catalytic performance of β-MnO2. Typically, the oxygen species contained within a catalyst are critical for the oxidation of HMF into FDCA. As such, the chemical properties of these oxygen species were examined using XPS. The peak observed at approximately 529.6 eV is attributed to lattice oxygen (O2 2-, denoted as OL). The peak found around 531.1 eV is due to the surface adsorbed oxygen (OA or O-) and OH groups (denoted as OV); the peak around 533.1 eV is related to the adsorbed molecular water (denoted as OW) [25,26]. By calculating the lattice oxygen (OA) ratios OA/(OL+OA) for the three catalysts, it was found that the order of ratios of OA/(OL+OA) is β-MnO2 (0.8125) > α-MnO2 (0.7474) > γ-MnO2 (0.7320). This ratio correlates positively with the initial oxidation rates of the HMF (Figure S6). Conversely, no correlation was observed between OL/(OL+OA) ratio and HMF initial oxidation rate (Figure S7), indicating that OL is crucial for the catalytic oxidation of HMF. Notably, β-MnO2 exhibits higher OL binding energies (529.90 eV and 530.11 eV, respectively) compared to the O 1s peak binding energies of the OL in α-MnO2 (529.70 eV and 529.83 eV, respectively). Combined with the previous analysis, the differences are attributed to β-MnO2 having a relatively smooth surface, which allows for greater electron accumulation and enhanced electron transfer between the small metal molecules on the catalyst surface and their adjacent O atoms, leading to an increased OL ratio. Further XPS analyses of the recovered α-MnO2, β-MnO2 and γ-MnO2 (Figure S8) revealed a slight decrease in the OL ratios (β-MnO2 -r (0.8071) > α-MnO2 -r (0.7410) > γ-MnO2 -r (0.7410)), which, in conjunction with XRD results, suggests that the reduction in the OL could be attributed to the agglomeration of particles during the catalytic process, forming larger particles that diminish surface electron transfer. Similarly, the performance of the recovered catalysts (Table S3) showed a slight decrease in catalytic activity, which correlates with the reduced OL ratio. In summary, β-MnO2 demonstrates a higher yield of FDCA compared to α-MnO2, despite having a lower specific surface area. Moreover, the oxidizing activity of β-MnO2 per unit of specific surface area is also is also found to be inferior to that of α-MnO2. Therefore, combined with various characterizations, it is hypothesized that the superior catalytic performance of β-MnO2 may be due to its relatively smooth catalytic surface, which retains a greater number of electrons. This electron enrichment is believed to boost the concentration of OL, thereby enhancing the catalyst's overall activity. 3.3 Modification of β-MnO2 and α-MnO2 In the petrochemical field, the method of improving the adsorptive properties of activated carbon through nitric acid modification, which involves disrupting the pore structure, is well-established [27,28]. The underlying mechanism is that nitric acid treatment increases the presence of acidic oxygen-containing functional groups such as carboxyls, lactones, and phenolic hydroxyls on the activated carbon's surface. These acidic groups lead to an expansion of the pore diameter and the removal of surface impurities, resulting in a smoother surface texture and a more robust adsorption capacity. According to this characteristic, both α-MnO2 and β-MnO2 catalysts underwent nitric acid treatment to refine their surface smoothness. Additionally, the grinding duration for these catalysts was extended to augment their specific surface area. However, it was discovered that an increased specific surface area did not necessarily translate into improved catalytic activity. The N2 adsorption-desorption tests showed that the specific surface area of the two MnO2 catalysts nearly doubled following multiple grinding processes, but it slightly diminished after aqueous nitric acid immersion treatment (Table 4 ). This was primarily due to the collapse of some pore walls during the nitric acid treatment, while the oxidation process introduced oxygen-containing functional groups on the surface of the catalysts, which subsequently blocked the pores and decreased the specific surface area. Scanning electron microscopy of the HNO3-modified catalysts confirmed that the spikes on the MnO2 particles were largely eliminated (Figure S9), validating the impact of the HNO3 immersion treatment. However, the increase in specific surface area did not improve the activity of the catalysts (Table 5 ). On the contrary, the catalytic activity of the catalysts treated with aqueous nitric acid solution increased dramatically, supporting the earlier hypothesis. However, the increase in the catalytic activity was more pronounced for α-MnO2, as the initial β-MnO2 catalyst had a smoother crystal structure with fewer small nanorods or amorphous particles compared to the α-MnO2 catalyst. Interestingly, the nitric acid-treated catalysts subjected to the same extended milling time exhibited similar catalytic activity to those treated with nitric acid alone, indicating that the specific surface area size is not the sole determinant of the catalytic activity for the Mn-based catalysts. To further illustrate this hypothesis, the catalysts treated by different methods were analyzed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, and the XPS energy spectra of their O 1s are shown in Figure S10 (a, b). The relative amounts of OL in the catalysts are as follows: α-MnO2-H+ (0.8627)>β-MnO2-H+ (0.8147)>β-MnO2 (0.8125)>β-MnO2-G (0.8077)>α-MnO2-G (0.7891)>α-MnO2 (0.7474). This sequence corresponds to the observed catalytic activities. The OL content of both catalysts treated with the dilute nitric acid immersion was greatly improved [29], confirming that this method can boost catalytic activity by eliminating amorphous components, such as precursors or ions of α-MnO2, that were not fully transformed during the synthesis process, rather, it is the OL content that plays the decisive role. Although the specific surface area of the two catalysts treated by extended milling was doubled, the OL ratio remained largely unchanged, and the catalytic activity remained consistent, demonstrating that the specific surface area is not the critical factor affecting the catalytic activity of the MnO2 catalysts; rather, it is the OL content that plays the decisive role. It is well known that OA and OL are the main oxygen species involved in the oxidation process. To further determine the roles of these two oxygen species in catalyzing the oxidation of HMF to generate FDCA, we employed O2-TPD to track the transformation of oxygen in α-MnO2, α-MnO2-H+, β-MnO2, and β-MnO2-H+. (Fig. 5 (a, b)). The O2-TPD spectra were divided into three temperature regions: low temperature (LT, <350°C), medium temperature (MT, 350-650°C) and high temperature (HT, >650°C) [30,31]. It is generally believed that the desorption peaks in the LT region correspond to weakly chemisorbed oxygen atoms and surface-bound atoms. The resolved peaks observed at intermediate temperatures belong to strongly chemisorbed oxygen, i.e., OA, whereas the resolved peaks observed at high temperatures belong to lattice oxygen, OL. While differences between the same catalysts at LT and MT stages were not pronounced, significant variations were observed in the HT phase for both α-MnO2 and α-MnO2-H+ as well as β-MnO2 and β-MnO2-H+. Notably, the nitrate-treated catalysts all showed large desorption peaks in the HT phase, aligning with their catalytic performance and underscoring OL's direct involvement in HMF oxidation. The above results indicate that the HNO3-treated catalysts enhance the mobility of OL, further corroborating the direct participation of OL, rather than OA, in the oxidation of HMF. Based on the Mars-van Krevelen (MvK) mechanism [32], it is reasonable to infer that the high mobility of lattice oxygen contributes to the efficient oxidation of HMF to generate FDCA. In addition, the acidic sites of the catalysts also affect the performance of the catalysts, therefore, the surface acidity of different crystalline MnO2 catalysts was also analyzed using NH3-TPD. (Fig. 5(c,d)). The temperature regions of the resolved peaks can be divided into three distinct ranges, corresponding to weak (<200°C), medium (200°C∼450°C), and strong (>450°C) acidic sites [8]. The acidic sites on the surface of MnO2 are mainly generated by the ligand-unsaturated Mn species (Mn+) in the [MnO6]- octahedron, a phenomenon previously discussed in the context of enhanced acidity activated charcoal treated with the nitrate modification method in the chemical industry [33]. Similarly, the enhancement of the absorption peaks in the acidic sites of both catalysts following dilute nitric acid immersion treatment demonstrates that nitric acid modification can similarly enhance acidity in the field of catalysis. The results of the optimization of the conditions for FDCA are shown in Fig. 6 . It is well known that the reaction temperature is an important parameter in the reaction process, and the yield of FDCA was less than 5% when the reaction temperature was 90 °C. Upon raising the temperature to 120 °C, HMF was almost completely converted, and the intermediate product FFCA was also basically completely converted, with the yield of FDCA reaching the maximum (97%) (Fig. 6c). The temperature-dependent results showed that increasing the temperature could accelerate the reaction process, however, both HMF conversion and FDCA yield exhibited a downward trend d with further reaction temperature increase. This may be because some HMF was deteriorated to humus by the high reaction temperature. Therefore, 120 °C was selected as the optimal reaction temperature for subsequent optimization. The reaction time also played an important role in the yield of FDCA, and the HMF was transformed in only 1 h, but the yield of FDCA was only 3% at this time. With the extension of the reaction time, the yield increased steadily and reached the maximum at 8 h (Fig. 6a). By further extending the reaction time, the FDCA yield began to decrease, which was attributed to the decomposition of a small amount of FDCA into formic acid, acetylpropionic acid, and other substances under the action of high O2 concentration. Therefore, the conditions of the reaction were optimized using 8 h. The concentration of O2 also affects the FDCA yield. It was found that when the O2 pressure was lower than 2 MPa, the yield of FDCA increased with the increase of O2 pressure and reached the maximum value at 2 MPa. However, when the pressure of O2 exceeds 2 MPa, the yield of FDCA starts to decrease (Fig. 6b). Previous work [34,35] has shown that the furan ring is not stable enough at high O2 atmospheres and may break to form alcohols. Therefore, the optimum condition for O2 use during the reaction is 2 MPa. To reveal the mechanism of selective oxidation of HMF to FDCA by α-MnO2-H+ catalyst, the adsorption states of HMF, FA, and FF on the surface of α-MnO2 catalyst were analyzed by FT-IR spectroscopy using HMF, FA, and FF as model species (Fig. 7 ). When HMF was adsorbed on the surface of α-MnO2 catalyst, noticeable shifts in the IR absorption peaks at 1680 cm-1 (C=O) and 3430 cm-1 (O-H) were observed, whereas the peak associated with the furan ring of HMF at 1460 cm-1 remained unaltered. This indicates that the carbonyl and hydroxyl groups of HMF interact strongly with the surface of the α-MnO2-H+ catalyst, with little to no influence on the furan ring in HMF. The more pronounced shift towards the carbonyl group supports the notion that HMF is initially converted to HMFCA rather than DFF. It is well known that the recoverability of catalysts determines whether they can be adapted to the requirements of industrial production, therefore, we carried out the recovery and leaching test on α-MnO2-H+ catalysts (Fig. S11), fresh α-MnO2-H+ catalysts at 120 °C, and 98.5% FDCA yield could be obtained for 8 h. After the completion of the reaction, the reaction was cooled down to room temperature with ice water, and the reaction was separated from solids by centrifugation. After the reaction was completed, the reaction was cooled to room temperature with ice water, the liquid and solid were separated by centrifugation, and the catalyst was rinsed with ethanol three times and then dried in a 100 °C drying oven, and then the reaction was carried out under the same conditions. The results showed that the catalyst still had high catalytic activity even after five cycles, and the catalytic activity decreased only after the sixth cycle, which proved that the catalyst had good cyclic stability. In previous studies, it was found that α-MnO2 selectively and aerobically oxidized C=O on HMF via the Mn4+/Mn3+ redox cycle, which was accompanied by interconversion between lattice oxygen and oxygen vacancies (OL-OV), aligning with the Mars-van Krevelen redox mechanism. Based on these results, this paper proposes a reaction mechanism for the catalytic conversion of HMF to FDCA on the α-MnO2-H+ surface (Scheme 1 ). Initially, the carbonyl group in HMF was adsorbed on the surface of α-MnO2-H+ catalyst mediated by Mn4+ species exhibiting Lewis acidity. Under alkaline conditions, the aldehyde group would form a bis-diol and under the catalyst's influence, two hydrogen atoms were abstracted from the OL sites on the surface of the catalyst, leading to the formation of HMFCA. Subsequently, the hydroxyl group in HMFCA was also dissociated by the unsaturated Mn site in the catalyst. The hydroxyl group in HMFCA will also be adsorbed by the unsaturated Mn site in the catalyst and dissociated into alcohol oxygen, followed by extraction of the α-H group by another OL site, resulting in the formation of FFCA. FFCA is further oxidized to FDCA, mirroring the initial oxidation of the aldehyde to the carboxylate group. The whole process occurs through the interconversion between Mn4+ and Mn3+. 4 Conclusion In summary, we have investigated and developed a green and simple method to improve the catalytic activity of catalysts, i.e., treating different MnO2 catalysts with dilute nitric acid immersion to prepare the novel catalysts α-MnO2-H+. Comparative studies of the α-MnO2-H+ materials with ordinary α-MnO2 crystals showed that the nitric acid activation treatment could remove the small nanoparticles with low crystallinity or amorphous particles in the catalysts. thereby increasing the OA ratio of α-MnO2-H+ catalysts and greatly improving the catalytic performance of α-MnO2-H+ catalysts. Compared with all the monometallic non-precious metal catalysts reported so far for oxidizing HMF, the α-MnO2-H+ catalyst showed the best results. Under the milder reaction conditions (2 MPa O2, 120 °C, 8 h), the α-MnO2-H+ catalyst catalyzed the oxidation of HMF with a conversion of greater than 99.9% and the yield of FDCA was 98.5%. After five cycles, the catalytic activity of the α-MnO2-H+ catalyst was still high, which proved that the α-MnO2-H+ catalyst had good recyclability. Through the reaction kinetics study and FT-IR analysis, the mechanism of the MnO2 catalyst to catalyze HMF into FDCA was speculated, in which the cycling of Mn4+/Mn3+ plays a key role in the -CHO oxidation process. The treatment of the catalyst with the nitric acid immersion method provides a new idea for future catalyst preparation methods. coredata.dc:description: Investigating the various polymorphs of MnO2 for the catalytic oxidation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) to 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) is motivated by the pressing demand to engineer sustainable and proficient catalytic pathways. These pathways are essential for transforming renewable biomass into valuable chemicals, thereby facilitating the shift towards a circular economy and diminishing our dependence on fossil fuel-derived resources. Herein, three MnO2 catalysts with different crystal structures were prepared for the efficient catalytic oxidation of HMF to FDCA. The results showed that α-MnO2 exhibited higher oxidizing activity per unit specific surface area and an appreciably large specific surface area, however, its overall catalytic activity was found to be less than that of β-MnO2. XRD, SEM, and other characterizations suggest that the presence of smaller nanorods or amorphous particles with reduced crystallinity on the surface of the α-MnO2 catalysts could be responsible for a decreased lattice oxygen content, thereby diminishing their catalytic activity. To validate this conjecture, this paper cites for the first time the application of a dilute nitric acid immersion treatment in the chemical industry to eliminate amorphous structures from catalysts. The α-MnO2-H+ catalyst, prepared using this innovative method demonstrated exceptional activity in facilitating the conversion of HMF to FDCA under more stringent reaction conditions than any monometallic catalysts previously reported. According to the kinetic analysis of the reaction, it was established that the oxidation of 5-formyl-2-furancarboxylic acid (FFCA) to FDCA constitutes the rate-limiting step within the entire oxidation process. On this basis, FT-IR studies showed that the oxidation initiates at the -CHO terminus of HMF, leading to the formation of intermediates 5-hydroxymethylfurfurylacetic acid and 5-formylfurfurylacetic acid within the Mn4+/Mn3+ redox cycle. In conclusion, the enhancement of catalytic activity by diluting nitric acid immersion treatment presents a promising avenue for further research and application in the field of green chemistry.
coredata.dc:title: Aerobic oxidation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural to 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid by modification of the crystalline structure of MnO2 for catalytic purposes
